required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Tracking Physical Activity for Chronic Pain Management Among Older Adults in Detroit
clinical_study.official_title: Promoting Physical Activity for Chronic Pain Management Among Older Adults in Detroit: Comparing Technology-Based Strategies

brief_summary.textblock: Wearable, commercially-available physical activity monitors are being increasingly incorporated into chronic pain self-management interventions as a tool to help patients set goals and to tailor intervention content based on patient progress. Yet older adults from resource-challenged communities may face significant barriers to using these monitors and reporting activity data. Our pilot study will focus on wearable monitor use among older adults in Detroit with chronic musculoskeletal pain, testing the feasibility and validity of various technology-based strategies for reporting daily step count data. The study will also assess whether six weeks of monitor use is associated with improvements in functioning, relative to a control group.

primary_outcome.description: The Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS-29) Pain Interference 4-item subscale, where a higher score indicates more pain interference. Items ask how much pain in the last 7 days has interfered with daily activities such as household chores and social activities (1=not at all to 5=very much). Raw scores are converted to T-scores (normed such that a score of 50 is the population mean and 10 T-score points=1 standard deviation). The possible range is 42 to 76, with a higher score representing worse outcome.

primary_outcome.measure: Adherence to Step Count Reporting - SMS
primary_outcome.description: Proportion of days that step count was successfully provided/possible reporting days for SMS

primary_outcome.measure: Adherence to Step Count Reporting - IVR
primary_outcome.description: Proportion of days that step count was successfully provided/possible reporting days for IVR.

primary_outcome.measure: Adherence to Step Count Reporting - Sync
primary_outcome.description: Proportion of days that step count was successfully provided/possible reporting days for syncing with app

secondary_outcome.description: The Physical Functioning 4-item subscale of the Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS)-29 Adult Profile. Items ask how much difficulty participant has in doing daily activities such as household chores, using stairs, and walking 15 minutes (1=without any difficulty to 5=unable to do); raw total scale scores range from 4 (high functioning) to 20 (low functioning). When converted to T-scores (normed such that a score of 50 is the population mean and 10 T-score points=1 standard deviation), the possible range is 23 to 57, with a higher score representing worse outcome.

Ability to Participate in Social Roles and Activities, a 4-item subscale from PROMIS-20 rating the amount of trouble (1=not at all to 5=very much) in participating in social roles such as family activities, leisure activities, and work. Raw total scale scores range from 4 (high functioning) to 20 (low functioning). When converted to T-scores (normed such that a score of 50 is the population mean and 10 T-score points=1 standard deviation), the possible range is 29 to 64, with a higher score representing worse outcome.

secondary_outcome.measure: Validity of Manually-reported Step Count Data - SMS
secondary_outcome.description: Correlation of manually-reported SMS data with automatically uploaded data - percentage of days that counts are within 50 steps of each other

secondary_outcome.measure: Validity of Manually Reported Step Count Data - IVR
secondary_outcome.description: Correlation of manually-reported SMS data with automatically uploaded data - percentage of days that counts are within 50 steps of each other

arm_group.description: Participants will receive a wearable physical activity monitor and will be asked to report their daily step count in 3 different ways (2 weeks each of SMS text messages, Interactive Voice Response calls (IVR), automatic upload) during the 6-week study period.
Participants in this group will not receive a wearable physical activity monitor and will not be asked to report their step count.

intervention.description: Participants in the STEPS (Seniors Tracking Exercise for Pain Self-management) intervention will receive a commercially-available, wearable physical activity monitor. They will be asked to wear this monitor during waking hours for 6 weeks, reporting their daily step count every evening. The way in which participants report steps will change every 2 weeks. For the first 4 weeks of the study, participants will report via Interactive Voice Response (IVR) calls for 2 weeks and SMS text messages for 2 weeks. For the final two week period, research staff will help participants to set up the monitor to automatically send daily step counts to STEPS project staff. This can be done through a smartphone, tablet, or computer.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age > 60 years
- Ambulatory with or without assistive device
- Community living
- Have a SMS-capable cell phone
- Internet access (via smartphone, in-home or elsewhere);
- Self-reported chronic musculoskeletal pain (pain in muscles or joints for > 3 months)
- >4 (0-10 scale) average pain level over last week
- >1 day/previous 30 when pain made it difficult to do usual activities
- Ability to travel to study location in Detroit for a one-time session
Exclusion criteria:
- Serious acute illness or hospitalization in last month
- Planned surgery in next month
- Severe cognitive impairment

overall_official.affiliation: University of Michigan School of Public Health

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

group.title: STEPS Intervention Group
group.description: Participants will receive a wearable physical activity monitor and will be asked to report their daily step count in 3 different ways (2 weeks each of SMS text messages, Interactive Voice Response calls (IVR), automatic upload) during the 6-week study period. STEPS Intervention: Participants in the STEPS (Seniors Tracking Exercise for Pain Self-management) intervention will receive a commercially-available, wearable physical activity monitor. They will be asked to wear this monitor during waking hours for 6 weeks, reporting their daily step count every evening. The way in which participants report steps will change every 2 weeks. For the first 4 weeks of the study, participants will report via Interactive Voice Response (IVR) calls for 2 weeks and SMS text messages for 2 weeks. For the final two week period, research staff will help participants to set up the monitor to automatically send daily step counts to STEPS project staff. This can be done through a smartphone, tablet, or computer.

group.title: STEPS Control Group
group.description: Participants in this group will not receive a wearable physical activity monitor and will not be asked to report their step count.

drop_withdraw_reason.title: Not able to attend required orientation

baseline.population: Note: This is the analytic sample (i.e., participants with baseline and 8-week follow-up data, representing 51 of 57 randomized.)

group.title: STEPS Intervention Group
group.description: Participants will receive a wearable physical activity monitor and will be asked to report their daily step count in 3 different ways (2 weeks each of SMS text messages, Interactive Voice Response calls (IVR), automatic upload) during the 6-week study period. STEPS Intervention: Participants in the STEPS (Seniors Tracking Exercise for Pain Self-management) intervention will receive a commercially-available, wearable physical activity monitor. For the first 4 weeks of the study, participants will report via Interactive Voice Response (IVR) calls for 2 weeks and SMS text messages for 2 weeks. For the final two week period, research staff will help participants to set up the monitor to automatically send daily step counts to STEPS project staff. This can be done through a smartphone, tablet, or computer.

group.title: STEPS Control Group
group.description: Participants in this group will not receive a wearable physical activity monitor and will not be asked to report their step count.

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measure.title: Pain intensity in last week
measure.description: Pain intensity rated on 1 to 10 scale, where 1=no pain and 10=worst imaginable pain).

measure.title: PROMIS 4-item pain interference T-score
measure.description: Items ask how much pain in the last 7 days has interfered with daily activities such as household chores and social activities (1=not at all to 5=very much). Converted to population-normed T-score (population mean of 50).

measure.title: PROMIS 4-item physical function difficulty T-score
measure.description: Items ask how much difficulty participant has in doing daily activities such as household chores, using stairs, and walking 15 minutes (1=without any difficulty to 5=unable to do). Converted to population-normed T-score (population mean of 50).

measure.title: PROMIS 4-item social partcipation T-score
measure.description: Items assess difficulty participating in family activities, leisure activities, and work 1=not at all to 5=very much). Converted to population-normed T-score (population mean of 50).

outcome.title: Change in Pain Interference
outcome.description: The Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS-29) Pain Interference 4-item subscale, where a higher score indicates more pain interference. Items ask how much pain in the last 7 days has interfered with daily activities such as household chores and social activities (1=not at all to 5=very much). Raw scores are converted to T-scores (normed such that a score of 50 is the population mean and 10 T-score points=1 standard deviation). The possible range is 42 to 76, with a higher score representing worse outcome.
outcome.population: This is from the analytic sample that had both baseline and follow-up data on this measure. Change score is the follow-up minus baseline score, such that a greater, negative change value is a better outcome.

group.title: STEPS Intervention Group
group.description: Participants will receive a wearable physical activity monitor and will be asked to report their daily step count in 3 different ways (2 weeks each of SMS text messages, Interactive Voice Response calls (IVR), automatic upload) during the 6-week study period. STEPS Intervention: Participants in the STEPS (Seniors Tracking Exercise for Pain Self-management) intervention will receive a commercially-available, wearable physical activity monitor. They will be asked to wear this monitor during waking hours for 6 weeks, reporting their daily step count every evening. The way in which participants report steps will change every 2 weeks. For the first 4 weeks of the study, participants will report via Interactive Voice Response (IVR) calls for 2 weeks and SMS text messages for 2 weeks. For the final two week period, research staff will help participants to set up the monitor to automatically send daily step counts to STEPS project staff. This can be done through a smartphone, tablet, or computer.

group.title: STEPS Control Group
group.description: Participants in this group will not receive a wearable physical activity monitor and will not be asked to report their step count.

measure.title: Change in Pain Interference
measure.description: The Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS-29) Pain Interference 4-item subscale, where a higher score indicates more pain interference. Items ask how much pain in the last 7 days has interfered with daily activities such as household chores and social activities (1=not at all to 5=very much). Raw scores are converted to T-scores (normed such that a score of 50 is the population mean and 10 T-score points=1 standard deviation). The possible range is 42 to 76, with a higher score representing worse outcome.
measure.population: This is from the analytic sample that had both baseline and follow-up data on this measure. Change score is the follow-up minus baseline score, such that a greater, negative change value is a better outcome.

outcome.title: Adherence to Step Count Reporting - SMS
outcome.description: Proportion of days that step count was successfully provided/possible reporting days for SMS
outcome.population: Intervention group participants with baseline and follow-up data. Excludes one case that did not have a texting plan on her phone. Result represents number of adherent person-days out of all possible person-days for SMS.

group.title: STEPS Intervention Group
group.description: This analysis was only conducted on the Intervention group, who participated in 6 weeks of tracking and reporting step counts.

measure.title: Adherence to Step Count Reporting - SMS
measure.description: Proportion of days that step count was successfully provided/possible reporting days for SMS
measure.population: Intervention group participants with baseline and follow-up data. Excludes one case that did not have a texting plan on her phone. Result represents number of adherent person-days out of all possible person-days for SMS.

outcome.title: Adherence to Step Count Reporting - IVR
outcome.description: Proportion of days that step count was successfully provided/possible reporting days for IVR.
outcome.population: Intervention group participants with baseline and follow-up data. Excludes one case who did not receive IVR calls on schedule due to system error. Result represents number of adherent person-days out of all possible person-days for IVR.

group.title: STEPS Intervention Group
group.description: This analysis was only conducted on the Intervention group, who participated in 6 weeks of tracking and reporting step counts.

measure.population: Intervention group participants with baseline and follow-up data. Excludes one case who did not receive IVR calls on schedule due to system error. Result represents number of adherent person-days out of all possible person-days for IVR.

outcome.description: Proportion of days that step count was successfully provided/possible reporting days for syncing with app
outcome.population: Intervention group participants with baseline and follow-up data. Result represents number of adherent person-days out of all possible person-days for sync.

group.title: STEPS Intervention Group

outcome.title: Change in Physical Functioning
outcome.description: The Physical Functioning 4-item subscale of the Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS)-29 Adult Profile. Items ask how much difficulty participant has in doing daily activities such as household chores, using stairs, and walking 15 minutes (1=without any difficulty to 5=unable to do); raw total scale scores range from 4 (high functioning) to 20 (low functioning). When converted to T-scores (normed such that a score of 50 is the population mean and 10 T-score points=1 standard deviation), the possible range is 23 to 57, with a higher score representing worse outcome.
outcome.population: Participants who had data on both baseline and follow-up measure. Change score is the follow-up minus baseline score, such that a greater, negative change value is a better outcome.

group.title: STEPS Intervention Group
group.description: Participants will receive a wearable physical activity monitor and will be asked to report their daily step count in 3 different ways (2 weeks each of SMS text messages, Interactive Voice Response calls (IVR), automatic upload) during the 6-week study period. STEPS Intervention: Participants in the STEPS (Seniors Tracking Exercise for Pain Self-management) intervention will receive a commercially-available, wearable physical activity monitor. They will be asked to wear this monitor during waking hours for 6 weeks, reporting their daily step count every evening. The way in which participants report steps will change every 2 weeks. For the first 4 weeks of the study, participants will report via Interactive Voice Response (IVR) calls for 2 weeks and SMS text messages for 2 weeks. For the final two week period, research staff will help participants to set up the monitor to automatically send daily step counts to STEPS project staff. This can be done through a smartphone, tablet, or computer.

Items ask how much difficulty participant has in doing daily activities such as household chores, using stairs, and walking 15 minutes (1=without any difficulty to 5=unable to do); raw total scale scores range from 4 (high functioning) to 20 (low functioning). When converted to T-scores (normed such that a score of 50 is the population mean and 10 T-score points=1 standard deviation), the possible range is 23 to 57, with a higher score representing worse outcome.
measure.population: Participants who had data on both baseline and follow-up measure. Change score is the follow-up minus baseline score, such that a greater, negative change value is a better outcome.

outcome.title: Change in Social Participation
outcome.description: Ability to Participate in Social Roles and Activities, a 4-item subscale from PROMIS-20 rating the amount of trouble (1=not at all to 5=very much) in participating in social roles such as family activities, leisure activities, and work. Raw total scale scores range from 4 (high functioning) to 20 (low functioning). When converted to T-scores (normed such that a score of 50 is the population mean and 10 T-score points=1 standard deviation), the possible range is 29 to 64, with a higher score representing worse outcome.
outcome.population: Participants who had data on both baseline and follow-up measure. Change score is the follow-up minus baseline score, such that a greater, negative change value (or smaller positive value) is a better outcome.

outcome.title: Validity of Manually-reported Step Count Data - SMS
outcome.description: Correlation of manually-reported SMS data with automatically uploaded data - percentage of days that counts are within 50 steps of each other
outcome.population: Result is number of person- days with valid data reported that were within 50 steps of sync value.

group.title: STEPS Intervention Group
group.description: This analysis was only conducted on the Intervention group, who participated in 6 weeks of tracking and reporting step counts.

event.description: Participant was hospitalized for pneumonia. Not related to research.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
